MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Central Statistics Office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he is satisfied with the accuracy of the industrial productions statistics and the trade figures published by the CSO.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he is satisfied with the reliability of our economic statistics as published.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 1 and 2 together.

I am satisfied that the economic statistics published by the CSO meet a very high standard of reliability and compare fully, in this respect, with those published by statistical offices in other countries. As Deputies familiar with statistical material will be aware, this does not mean that statistics once published will never have to be revised. It is recognised professionally that all statistics are subject to some margin of error. This margin will vary, in particular, with the method of collection. The CSO frequently includes in the publication of statistics indications of the degree of reliability of particular figures or sets of figures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Has the attention of the Taoiseach been drawn to press reports of statements attributed to Mr. John Lynch, Director of the Irish Computer Centre, in which he suggests that the trade figures may be unreal. Would the Taoiseach care to comment on that statement?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am not familiar with the statement nor do I understand what is meant by the word “unreal” in that context.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I should draw Deputy Haughey's attention to the fact that quotations are not permitted at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I am not going to quote anything. Is the Taoiseach aware that this statement appeared in The Irish Times on 13 October? Mr. Lynch explained very clearly what he meant and indicated that in his view the figures at that point were somewhat unreliable.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy asking a further question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: As the Taoiseach indicated he did not know about the statement or what was meant by “unreal”, is he aware that this statement was on the front page of The Irish Times and that Mr. Lynch made it clear what he meant by describing these figures?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Statistics can be open to misinterpretation in areas such as new industries of different character. Some have added value present and others have not. It is quite a complex area but I would be happy to deal with a specific question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach aware of the rather startling turn-around which is supposed to have taken place with trade figures during the month of August? Exports are supposed to have——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is the name of all that is holy how can I not quote statistics?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The questions on the Order Paper are general questions and the Deputy is now introducing a specific item.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I am only proving that the figures are wrong by giving instances and that there is something seriously wrong with the trade figures published by the CSO.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: In the Chair's opinion, that could lead to endless supplementary questions on various matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The question on the Order Paper is very specific and asks the Taoiseach if he is satisfied with the accuracy of the trade figures published by the CSO. I am now asking the Taoiseach if he is aware of the fact that the trade figures published by the CSO for August show a drop of £180 million in actual figures and show a complete turn-around of about £300 million in many cases and if he is aware of any explanation for this rather big turn-around in these statistics? Is he satisfied that these statistics are correct or do they throw some doubt on the series of figures published by the CSO for 1984?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy put down a question on the accuracy of production statistics and I would be happy to answer it. There are many reasons for variation in the figures both here and in other countries. This happens for a variety of reasons, some because of major transactions occurring normally in one month and because of large consignments coming in and out in a particular month. I am satisfied with our trade statistics and that data furnished by the CSO has been accurate in the past. With regard to the particular case, if Deputy Haughey puts down a specific question I will be happy to answer it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: There is no reason for me to put down a specific question. The figures are published by the CSO. Would the Taoiseach consider that the figures given by the CSO for increases in our exports in 1984 appear to be at variance with 1983? In January it was 39 per cent, in February it was 31 per cent, in March 46 per cent, in April 19 per cent, in May 50 per cent, in June 31 per cent, in July 22 per cent and in August 5 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy has quoted figures. The fact is that the oscillations in the figures from month to month are in accordance with the usual trend and the fluctuations tend to level out between different sectors. The oscillations to which the Leader of the Opposition referred are ones which have occurred throughout the whole history of the State in accordance with month to month trade statistics. If the Deputy had taken the opportunity to examine the figures in detail, he would be aware of that fact.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach accept that in regard to the White Paper on Industrial Development and a procession or series of oscillations which have been presented in the economic plan, there are serious doubts about the accuracy of the figures for industrial output, for export performance or the size of the labour force, and that the whole exercise should certainly be called into question? Would he not agree that there is a combination of instances, beginning with the famous £500 million black hole at the beginning of the year and continuing with the mistakes with regard to the milk production figures for the EEC milk super-levy and the rather peculiar pattern of our export statistics supposed to have taken place in the month of August? These show a clear discrepancy between the figures of the Industrial White Paper and the plan, as it is called, in the areas of figures with regard to the labour force. Is the Taoiseach aware that all these and many similar matters combine to cast serious doubt in this whole area and on the figures being put forward by the Government and that this leads one to regard the recent document published by the Government as a very dubious exercise, indeed?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am aware, as the Deputy has now indicated by showing his hand, of the purpose which lies behind his question and the manner in which he is prepared to——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Answer the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: No speech.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: ——cast doubt of one kind or another on the work of the Government and the Government plan and Industrial White Paper. A number of the points which he has made should be answered individually and I would be happy to do so another time, such as the closing speech in the debate.

As far as the milk figures are concerned, the Central Statistics Office furnished to the EEC provisional figures — marked provisional — in the normal way in respect of returns which they had received. The ordinary revision was carried out in the usual manner. The Deputy will not be able to fault the CSO with regard to the figures being marked provisional. I am open to answer in detail the other points in public time. The Deputy ought to consider where he stands in this matter. If he is seeking to undermine the credibility of the figures——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It is your figures. Answer for your own figures.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: ——provided by the Central Statistics Office, as the Deputy knows that office is run as a professional body and is not amenable to influence or pressure of any kind. Their directors have withstood attempts in the past to influence them and have threatened to resign because of political pressure. The Leader of the Opposition must know that his attempt to cast aspersions on them of this kind in unworthy of him and of his party and damaging to the national interest.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Might the Chair suggest that this debate would be more appropriate to item 7 of today's Order Paper?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach has just made a number of insinuations. In reply to his last point, could I ask him whether he has seen fit himself to establish a special committee or body to supervise the procedures of the CSO and whether that does not completely undermine his rather tendentious statement about the CSO? Further——

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy like me to answer that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: ——it is perfectly legitimate and correct for me to query various important statistics which have been put forward, particularly so when in recent times figures have been grossly mistaken. One might have been prepared to ignore one mistake but when there are a series of mistaken figures in key and crucial areas of the economy, it is very legitimate for me to comment on them, not so much in connection with the CSO but with the Government's acceptance of figures from different quarters to support the spurious document that they have just published?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In reply to the first point, the Statistics Council are a professional body who have consistently remained independent, which is of extreme importance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: But they are consistently being supervised.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: They formulate and present statistical data on an independent basis.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Building on Reality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach what expert economic advice was available to him from within Government Departments, when drawing up the document Building on Reality.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Government made use of the range of expertise available to them from within Government Departments in preparing the national plan Building on Reality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach care to comment on persistent rumours to the effect that the advice of the higher echelon of the Department of Finance and of the Central Bank were completely ignored by the Government in the preparation and formulation of the document which was published recently?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Such a comment would be more appropriate to a debate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Unfortunately, this is Question Time. We have Question Time every day and we cannot anticipate any item on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: First, I want to rebut totally the innuendo of the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It is not an innuendo. It is a statement.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It is a question and a statement.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy has referred to rumours being circulated and in view of the nature of the allegation made and the fact that the national plan includes a whole range of figures it many require from me a rather long reply, but it is important to answer this allegation.

Macroeconomic projections of price change and economic growth were based on EEC Commission forecasts for the world economy and prepared by the Budget and Planning Division of the Department of Finance in consultation with the Department of Agriculture, including use of the Central Bank/ Department of Finance econometric model of the Irish economy to check for internal consistency.

MainHeading.P: The labour force projections used the results of a special study prepared by a group of demographic experts, including experts from outside the Civil Service. These results, completed in July, (too late for inclusion in Industrial Policy White Paper) indicated labour force growth over the period of the plan ranging from 10,000 per annum (high emigration) to 15,000 per annum (low emigration). (The plan used low emigration forecast.)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The consistency of the employment figures with the growth projections were verified by the Budget and Planning Division of the Department of Finance in consultation with the Department of Labour. Contributions on employment and efficiency were from all relevant Departments, particularly Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism, Agriculture, Communications, Environment, Energy and the Public Service. This chapter on the long term unemployed was mainly the responsibility of the Department of Labour. Contributions on social policy were from all relevant Departments, particularly Education, Health, Social Welfare and Environment. The chapter on taxation was the responsibility of the Department of Finance. On public finances the costings of expenditure measures agreed by Government were carried out by the Public Expenditure Division of the Department of Finance.

Computation of the resulting budgetary profile, with forecasts of the current budget deficit, Exchequer and public sector borrowing, and the national debt were carried out by the Budget and Planning Division of the Department of Finance.

The group preparing the plan was chaired by my Department. This group had respresentatives of the Ministers for Energy, Environment, Finance (2), Health, Industry Trade, Commerce and Tourism, and Labour.

MainHeading.P: I am glad to have had the opportunity to clarify that, before the Leader of the Opposition lets that hare run. I should like to add that every figure in respect of the public finances in the document was prepared by and authorised by the Department of Finance. We were meticulous in ensuring that was the case. We have not used the practice used on one occasion some years ago by another Government of simply adjusting the figures by £130 million and knocking £5 million or £10 million off various Departments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: That is all old hat.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: It may be old hat but it will not be forgotten by the people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It would help everybody if the Taoiseach would stick to his own responsibilities and defend his own spurious figures if he can. I am glad that the Taoiseach has acknowledged the discrepancy between the key and crucial figures——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach aware that he has now for the first time admitted the realities which I have been pointing out about the discrepancy between the key and crucial area of labour force figures in the White Paper on industrial development which gave 15,000 and a paper published three months later which gave 17,000? Does the Taoiseach not accept that that gives very great credence to my entire argument?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling the next question.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I must be entitled to reply to those allegations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I have not finished. Does the Taoiseach accept that between the unreal cash limits——

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy does not like to get the answers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: ——stipulated to be based on Government Departments, between all the hitherto unknown, but certainly definite additional local taxes and charges that are coming and between the discrepancy in regard to the labour force figures the whole economic plan exercise is now seen to be at least dubious and almost certainly spurious? Will he answer this question for me? Is it true that, either during the course of the preparation of this document or subsequent to it, six economists left the Department of Finance because they could not take what they were seeing being published?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: The handlers have replaced them.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: What has been demonstrated by the questions and answers given is the spuriousness of the Deputy's allegations. As I have pointed out the figures in the national plan are the most up-to-date projections prepared by a demographic group of experts including two outsiders who reported in July after the publication of the industrial policy. The basis the Government used was the low emigration basis of the alternative range offered. I am glad to have the opportunity to clarify that because the Deputy has been attempting to mislead public opinion on this issue. He will not get away with it. The more questions he asks in this House the more the spurious nature of his allegations will be exposed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: What about the six economists? The Taoiseach has not answered my question. Have six outside economists resigned from the Department of Finance?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 4.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: There are no outside economists in the Department of Finance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach afraid to answer?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have called Question No. 4.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is it true?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: There are no outside economists in the Department of Finance.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am ruling Deputy Haughey out of order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I must take it that it is true that six economists have left the Department of Finance.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Haughey will resume his seat. He is being disorderly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach cannot stand over this spurious document.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am sorry Sir ——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I will not allow a debate on this.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: There are no spurious figures in this document.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: The fiction writers are at it again.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Soviet Union Human Rights Campaigner.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make urgent representations to the Soviet Union regarding the serious condition of the Human Rights campaigner Andrei Sakharov and his wife who are on hunger strike and reportedly being force-fed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs)
Speaker.P: The Deputy's question was tabled in May last, when there were reports that Dr. Sakharov was on hunger strike. I have no detailed information about the present circumstances of Dr. Sakharov and his wife, since they appear to have been effectively isolated from the outside world.

MainHeading.P: Like Deputy Taylor, I am concerned about the predicament of Dr. Sakharov and his wife. In this context, the Deputy will be aware that the Foreign Minister of France, Mr. Claude Cheysson, acting of behalf of the ten member states of the European Community, addressed to Mr. Andrei Gromyko, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, a letter concerning the situation of Dr. Sakharov and his wife. The letter was delievered on 19 May. This démarche by the Ten was undertaken for humanitarian reasons and in the spirit of the Helsinki Final Act.

I continue to hope that following the approach made on behalf of the Ten the government of the Soviet Union will act in the spirit of the Helsinki Final Act and will ensure humane treatment for Dr. Sakharov and his wife.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that the very fact that there has been no information to hand about Andrei Sakharov and his wife over these past months is a matter of increasing concern? In the circumstances would the Minister agree to make his own representations to the ambassador of the Soviet Union in Dublin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I think the Soviet authorities are fully aware of the concern of this Government and of all the governments of the Ten in regard to the position of Andrei Sakharov and his wife. I do not rule out the Deputy's suggestion and will keep it under consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Is the position that no reply whatever, good, bad or indifferent, has been received from the Soviet Union to the representation made by the Ten? If there was a reply, could the Minister indicate to the House what it is?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am not aware if there has been a reply. In the nature of the diplomatic procedure of the démarche it might not call for a formal reply as the Deputy has in mind.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Government Relations with Libya.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on Government relations with Libya.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: Ireland and Libya agreed in July 1977 to establish diplomatic relations on a non-residential basis. The Irish Ambassador to Italy is currently also accredited to Tripoli. The head of the Libyan People's Bureau in London had been accredited to Dublin; following the breaking of relations between the UK and Libya no new arrangement has yet been made for Libyan accreditation to Dublin.

The Government were gravely concerned by remarks reported to have been made in April and May by Colonel Gaddafi about possible Libyan support for the IRA. We have made clear in a number of subsequent contacts with the Libyan authorities the total unacceptability of Libyan support for, or offers of support for the IRA.

Economic co-operation between Ireland and Libya is discussed in the Irish-Libyan Joint Commission on Economic, Industrial, Scientific and Technological Co-operation. That commission is due to meet in Tripoli this year but dates have not yet been arranged. Libya is an important market for Irish exports with the trade balance heavily in Ireland's favour. The Libyan authorities have urged the Government to redress the imbalance by purchasing Libyan oil. Cost is the main factor against this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware of the operation of Libyan extermination squads throughout Europe? Is account being taken to ensure that they do not and cannot operate against Libyan citizens in this country who are opponents of Colonel Gaddafi?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am aware of newspaper reports to the effect that the Deputy suggests. Of course, the security forces of the State will be always alert to guard against any such happening in this jurisdiction.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give us the latest figures for trade with Libya? Is it still the case that, while we have exports worth tens of millions of pounds to Libya, our imports are virtually nil?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: It is not a case that our imports are virtually nil. As I indicated in answer to the question, the balance is in our favour. In 1983 our exports were worth IR£49 million while imports were valued in IR£25.8 million. Therefore, the balance is heavily in our favour, but it is not true to say that our imports are virtually nil, far from it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give us reasons why the meeting of the commission on the co-operation agreement which was established between the two countries which was scheduled to take place last May did not take place, having regard to the fact that we are in danger of losing very lucrative markets with the Libyans unless we are seen to be serious about the way we do our business with them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I think that the Deputy is satisfied that we are serious about how we do our business with Libya and any other country with which we trade. I have no reason as to why the meeting the Deputy refers to was postponed, but the Deputy can be satisfied that it will not be postponed in any way that would prejudice our trade.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Did the initiative for the postponement of the meeting scheduled for earlier this year come from this Government or the Libyan government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I have not got that information. If the Deputy puts down a separate question I will get the information for him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Will the Minister communicate that information to me?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I will.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Diplomatic Relations with Nicaragua.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if the Government will agree to the establishment of diplomatic relations with Nicaragua; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: It would be inappropriate and contrary to international practice to speculate publicly on the question of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Ireland and any other country with which we do not already have diplomatic relations as this would be a matter for discussion between the Irish Government and any other government concerned. The establishment of diplomatic relations with other countries is a matter which is kept under continuous review in the light of our international interests and availability of the necessary resources.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Could the Minister indicate whether the authorities in Nicaragua have requested the establishment of diplomatic relations? In view of the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the UN that the political and economic dialogue would be intensified between the Ten and the Central American countries, would the establishment of diplomatic relations not be useful to enable such intensified political contacts to take place?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Anti-Nicaraguan Government Moves.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Israeli Embassy in Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if the Israeli government have requested permission to open an embassy in Dublin; if permission has been granted by the Irish Government; if so, when the embassy will be opened; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: As I said, it would be inappropriate, and contrary to international practice, for me to say anything one way or the other on those reports whether they are persistent or occasional. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Will the Minister agree that all other EC countries have exchanged residential embassies with Israel and that it would be in our interests for the purpose of promoting trade, in agriculture, in particular, and in tourism, if residential ambassadors were exchanged? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: Will the Minister indicate whether the Government are reviewing the position as to whether a residential embassy should be provided in Ireland for the Israeli State and by this State providing a residential embassy in Israel in the context of the anomalous position created whereby we do have residential ambassadors to Iran, Egypt and the Lebanon? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: Will the Minister confirm that where countries have requested residential facilities for embassies in Ireland on occasion it has been agreed they could establish residential embassies here while we maintain our diplomatic relations through non-residential ambassadors? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Visit of Israeli President.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa

The invitation was officially conveyed some time ago and has been accepted. The programme for the visit remains to be settled in detail, but it is expected that President Herzog will come to Ireland towards the middle of 1985.

The invitation to President Herzog to visit Ireland should be seen in the light of many links with this country. In so far as there are any implications beyond the strictly bilateral, the invitation should be viewed in the context of the Government's balanced policy on the problem of the Middle East. Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: The Minister, I am sure, would accept that the Israeli position in the Middle East is not an innocent one and, for that reason, the other Middle Eastern countries may view the Irish Government as taking a particular position on the conflict in the Middle East by inviting the President of Israel here? Would the Minister accept that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am not prepared to categorise the Israeli position in the Middle East and it would be inappropriate for me to do so. I do not think it is inappropriate for us to invite the President of Israel to visit our country. MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Murder of Irish Nationals.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he is aware of widespread allegations that the South African authorities were responsible for the murder of an Irish passport holder (details supplied) and her six-year-old child, by a parcel bomb in Angola in June last; if he has made any representations to the South African authorities arising from this; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: As a Member who met Marius Schoon when he was in Dublin I should like to ask the Minister if in the event of the Angolan authorities not responding the Government will be prepared to register a protest with South Africa, indeed, to seek an explanation from the South African authorities in regard to their involvement in this incident and to afford them the opportunity of indicating what, if any, views they hold on the tragic deaths that occurred in this family?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Oireachtas Members' Cyprus Visit.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he is aware that a number of Members of the Oireachtas have recently visited that part of Cyprus now occupied by Turkish forces, apparently as guests of the illegal regime in that area; if the Minister was consulted before the trip; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am aware of the visit in question, which took place during the summer of this year. On hearing of the proposed visit, I made efforts to discourage the Members of the Oireachtas concerned from proceeding with their plans and I made fully clear the Government's position on the question of Cyprus. Regrettably, not all of those who intended to make the visit heeded my advice, and in the event, some Members of the Oireachtas went ahead with the visit.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Central America.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if, in his capacity as President of the Council of Ministers of the EC, he plans any initiatives to help secure peace in Central America.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on his recent meeting with the Foreign Ministers of the Contadora countries in Latin America.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 15 and 16 together.

A significant step to help secure peace in Central America was taken on 28-29 September 1984 at the Ministerial Conference in San Jose, Costa Rica, which I attended as President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers of the European Community.

There was a total of 21 participating countries, namely the ten member states of the European Community, along with the Commission of the European Community; Spain, Portugal; the five Central American states of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua; and the four member countries of the Contadora group; Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela. All participating states with one exception were represented at Foreign Minister level.
The objective of the conference was to inaugurate a new structure of political and economic dialogue between the Ten and Central America. As I said in my opening address as President of the Council:

MainHeading.P: The present moment is a particularly opportune time for a new effort to foster and intensify that relationship, not only because of the forthcoming enlargement of the European Community to include two countries whose intimate links with Latin America need no elaboration by me, but also because the grave political and social crisis through which Central America is now passing calls for a special effort of support and co-operation from its European friends.

The Ten sought to provide support for the efforts of the states of Central America to bring peace and stability to that region. In an agreed final communiqué, the participants expressed their conviction that the process inaugurated by the Contadora countries represents the best opportunity to achieve a solution to the crisis in Central America. The conference recognised that progress has been made within the Contadora process and in this connection noted in particular the publication of the revised draft “Contadora Act for Peace and Co-operation in Central America”. The Ministers, in the words of the joint communiqué:

called on the states concerned to continue to make every effort to bring the Contadora process rapidly to final fruition through the signature of a comprehensive agreement which would bring peace to the region. They were agreed on the necessity for a practical commitment to the implementation of any such agreement by all the states in the region and all other countries which have interests there, and on the necessity for the verification and control of that implementation.

Political developments everywhere are influenced to an important degree by economic conditions; in the particular circumstances of Central America, there is a clear casual link between inequitable and inadequate social and economic structures and political tension. Another objective of the dialogue between Central America and Europe, therefore, is to support and underpin the political pacification process by placing interregional economic co-operation on a more organised and perhaps sounder foundation than at present and thus to set the stage for an intensification of that co-operation.

It was agreed that existing economic co-operation would be intensified, with priority going to regionally-oriented projects and to those of a social nature such as health programmes and those designed to give assistance to refugees. The Community formally announced its intention to start discussions as soon as possible with a view to negotiating an interregional framework agreement. In the words of the joint communiqué:

Both sides considered that the conclusion of an agreement of this type would confirm the political will of both regions to extend and develop their relations and that it would also help to reinforce relations between the Community and Latin America as a whole.

I believe that the conference will have contributed to a better understanding on the part of the European Community and its member states of the nature of the problems confronting the countries of the region; of their aspirations for greater political stability and their determination to find a genuinely regional solution to the crisis which they are facing. I also believe that the meeting provided the Central American countries themselves with an opportunity to further their own efforts at regional integration and to attain a better understanding of each other's concerns. The joint communiqué bears ample witness to this and constitutes an important statement of the desire of all the countries in the region to promote social justice, economic development and respect for human rights and democratic liberties.

Speaker.P: Does the Minister support the holding of free elections in Nicaragua and would he deplore any attempt internally or externally to interfere with them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The holding of free democratic elections would be deserving of our fullest support.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that there have been significant developments in the area in the last couple of weeks? Speaker.P: When did the investigation begin? Who is the investigating officer and what is his rank? Has he been appointed? Has a time been specified for completion of the investigation? Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: I asked the Minister if he would publish the results.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Is the Minister satisfied that the Garda are the best people to investigate themselves? Speaker.P: (Limerick East): The Garda Síochána is a disciplined force and the Commissioner is head of that force. Whether we proceed by way of internal Garda investigation or by means of a public inquiry, the initial investigation process would have to be conducted by members of the Garda Síochána. I am satisfied that at the moment the internal Garda inquiry will provide enough information for me to know whether a further or different type of investigation is necessary.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: The Minister is not ruling out a public inquiry?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I am not ruling out anything at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: Will the Minister assure us that whatever inquiry takes place it will examine the question of how the accused's statement was made available to the media and published in the press? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent

Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Nobody is above the law. That applies to members of the Garda Síochána the same as it applies to Deputies.
